articles.headline: ‘Glimmers of Hope’ for Grads
articles.snippet: Connections and credentials may help graduates find work in hot industries, but some economists are concerned about a shaky recovery.
articles.abstract: Connections and credentials may help graduates find work in hot industries, but some economists are concerned about a shaky recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: This spring’s college graduates face better job prospects than the dismal environment encountered by last year’s grads. But that doesn’t mean the job market is thriving.

articles.headline: Overseas Madoff Investors Settle With Banks
articles.snippet: About 720,000 investors outside the U.S. who lost money to Bernard L. Madoff have settled with their banks, receiving about $15.5 billion.
articles.abstract: About 720,000 investors outside the U.S. who lost money to Bernard L. Madoff have settled with their banks, receiving about $15.5 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — About 720,000 investors outside the United States who lost money to the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff have settled with their banks, receiving about $15.5 billion in all, according to law firms representing those victims of the fraud.
articles.byline: By Raphael Minder and Diana B. Henriques

articles.headline: In Europe, Britain May Face Largest Debt Hurdle
articles.snippet: Prime Minister David Cameron must close a British budget deficit now equal to 11 percent of gross domestic product.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron must close a British budget deficit now equal to 11 percent of gross domestic product.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As governments from Greece to Portugal to Spain try to sell markets on their budget-cutting zeal, the country that may face the biggest hurdle is Britain.

articles.headline: Hard Times Spur Ideas for Change
articles.snippet: Lean budgets and political pressures have forced many states to consider new ways of doing business.
articles.abstract: Lean budgets and political pressures have forced many states to consider new ways of doing business.
articles.lead_paragraph: As states around the country gird for another grim budget year, more leaders have begun to talk not of nipping, not of tucking, but, in essence, of turning government upside down and starting over. Ever growing is the list of states, municipalities and agencies with blue ribbon committees aimed at reconsidering what government should be.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Said to Expand Secret Actions in Mideast
articles.snippet: A secret directive by Gen. David H. Petraeus is aimed at disrupting militant groups and countering other threats.
articles.abstract: A secret directive by Gen. David H. Petraeus is aimed at disrupting militant groups and countering other threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top American commander in the Middle East has ordered a broad expansion of clandestine military activity in an effort to disrupt militant groups or counter threats in Iran, Saudi Arabia, Somalia and other countries in the region, according to defense officials and military documents.

articles.headline: A Behind-the-Scenes Firm in the Spotlight
articles.snippet: Transocean, used to performing technological feats out of the limelight, has been thrust into the public eye because of its role in the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.abstract: Transocean, used to performing technological feats out of the limelight, has been thrust into the public eye because of its role in the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: Transocean’s corporate motto is “We’re never out of our depth.”
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Tom Zeller Jr

articles.headline: To Prepay for a Crisis, or Not
articles.snippet: Because it isn’t clear what financial institution would be in a position to pay into an emergency fund once a crisis begins, the prepay version of the financial bill makes most sense.
articles.abstract: Because it isn’t clear what financial institution would be in a position to pay into an emergency fund once a crisis begins, the prepay version of the financial bill makes most sense.

articles.headline: Shaky Rule in Madagascar Threatens Trees
articles.snippet: Exploiting a political crisis, Malagasy timber barons are robbing the nation of its sylvan heritage, illegally cutting down scarce species of rosewood trees.
articles.abstract: Exploiting a political crisis, Malagasy timber barons are robbing the nation of its sylvan heritage, illegally cutting down scarce species of rosewood trees.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAROANSETRA, Madagascar — Exploiting a political crisis, Malagasy timber barons are robbing this island nation of its sylvan heritage, illegally cutting down scarce species of rosewood trees in poorly protected national parks and exporting most of the valuable logs to China.

articles.headline: Tighter Credit in Europe Tied to Turmoil in Stock Markets
articles.snippet: Investors are abandoning risky bets in the financial markets and rushing for safety, concerned that the flow of credit could slow, worsening Europe’s financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Investors are abandoning risky bets in the financial markets and rushing for safety, concerned that the flow of credit could slow, worsening Europe’s financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once more, Wall Street is running scared.
